div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Summer Rates will be charged from 2 May to 31 October.

For the convenience of families and others, a large portion of each ship's accommodation has been reserved for Egypt, so that Berths can be definitely engaged at once, as if the voyage were commencing at Port Said. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company's Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Tuesday for the present except the MONGOLIA, which is taking passengers to the Anglo-French Naval Review, and will not wait at Port-Said on 24/25 July. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. The Fare remains as usual.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.
GEORGE ROYLE, Esq. PORT-SAID.
Messrs. HABELDEN & Co. ALEXANDRIA.
F. G. DAVIDSON, Superintendent P. & O. S. N. Company in Egypt SUEZ.

div.p: FAST BRITISH PASSENGER STEAMERS
GREECE - TURKEY LINE.
Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.
PALESTINE - SYRIA LINE.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).
RED SEA LINE.

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company's Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.head: THE ANGLO-EGYPTIAN BANK, LIMITED.
div.p: LONDON, PARIS ALEXANDRIA, CAIRO MALTA, GIBRALTAR, TANTAH, AND PORT SAID.
The Anglo-Egyptian Bank. Limited, undertakes every description of banking business on the most favourable conditions.
Current accounts opened with commercial homes and private individuals in conformity with the custom of Bankers.
Fixed deposits for one year certain received at 8 per cent. per annum. Deposits at interest for shorter periods are also received at rates to be agreed upon.
Letters of Credit for the use of travellers are issued payable in all parts of the World.
Approved bills discounted.
Bills, documentary invoices, etc, collected.
Drafts and telegraphic transfers issued payable all over the World.
Foreign exchange bought and sold.
Advances made upon approved securities and upon cotton, cotton-seed, sugar and other merchandise.
The purchase and sale of stocks and shares on the London Stock Exchange; and on the local and Continental Bourses, undertaken.

Customers can deposit their valuables, bonds, etc., for safe custody in the Bank's fire-proof strong-rooms, and the Bank will attend to the collection of the coupons and drawn bonds so deporited as they fall due.
Mercantile credits issued.
Annuities, pensions, dividends, etc., collected.
All farther particulars and information can be obtained on application.
The officers and clerks of the Bank are pledged to secrecy as to the transactions of customers. 18-9-905

div.p: One of the finest and most up-to-date Hotels in the Metropolis. Situated in Sharia Soliman Pasha, the very centre of the healthiest and most fashionable quarter. div.head: The Egyptian Gazette
div.p: THE ENGLISH DAILY NEWSPAPER.
ESTABLISHED 1880.
Editor and Manager - -.R. SNELLING.
Price: ONE PIASTRE TARIFF.
TUESDAY, May 1, 1906.

div.head: OPEN SPACES FOR CAIRO.
div.p: We are not prepared to endorse the ea. logiams of "Ismail the Magnificent" with which the Low Coarts have lately echoed, bat we think a word of praise might be given to him for his conception of the aspect the Capital of a great country shoald present. His scheme of making Cairo an African Paris was conceive! on & saperb scale. Abɔve all he had an idea of the valae of land spacer—the largı of a great city--which the present controllers of affairs do not possess.For ten years Cairo has been ander going the procese described in "Alice in Wonderland" as "aglification." The lovely gardens I aglow with rozes have been superseded by huge buildings in the style of srohitecture known as the Squirm. Can any stractores be more hideously inartistic than the residences in modern Cairo! Oply lately it was proposed to build over the beautifal Esbekieh Gardens. The idea has been abandoned, bat it is devoutly to be wished that the community would resist every attempt to build on the few open spaces left. Trees, flowers, everything nataral and wholesome mast be done away with, and the resalt is that Cairo will soon be one of the most unhealthy cities in the world. The odours in some of the streets rival the various stenches which Coleridge amalt in Cologne. Why is this? Anyone who walks in the bye-streets of Cairo in the afternoon will find one of the explanations of the present state of things. All the refase acsama!ated daring the day : broken bottles, orange peal, dirty paper, filthy objeots of all kinds, are pitched on the pavements to fester while flies, mosquitoes, and anolean insects of all sorts collect in swarms. Let us hava so ne placas to which we may repair to get away from the sordid smells and hid 300g noises of modern Cairo.

div.head: LAND AND MORTGAGE COMPANY OF EGYPT.
div.p: The Land and Mortgage Company of Egypt, Ltd., ADRODDOES an issue of £400,000 of 4 per cent. debenture stock, of which £.7,200 is offered for subscription at par, and the remaining £382,800 is offered in exchange for the company's existing debentares. The company, the prospectus states, was incorporated in 1880. The nominal capital is £900,000. The company in 1881 issued £300,000 of debontores, no deemable by annual drawings, and bas from time to time since issued other redeemable debentures. Of these debentures there are at present opstanding debentares to the aggregate nominal amount of £382,800, which are redeemable by annual drawings extending to 1928, and the company has power, under the terms of the ontstanding debentares, to issue debentures from time to time to rank pari passu therewith as a first charge on the undertaking and assets ap to the total amount of £400,000. The natare of the company's basiness, which is mainly that of lending money on mortgage in Egypt, is such as to require the fall employ. ment of tha company's funds, and the process of making frequerit re-issues of debentures in order to replace those paid off in the drawings is troublesome and expensive, while the fact of having different series of debentares in the hands of the poblio and continual drawings for their redemption is inconvenient. The directors have, therefore, determined to create the above debentare stook with the objeot of removing these disadvantages. The company accordingly now offers to holders of existing debentares the option to ežobange their holdings for the new debentare stock on the following terms - namely:- For each £.00 5 per cent. debenture £100 of the debentore stock with a cash bonus of £x 10s, and for each £100 45 per cent. debentare £100 of the stock, with a cash bonus of £2. Holders of existing debentures to converting will retain the interest coupon dae 15th May next, and will receive the first warrant for interest on the debentare stock on the 11th November next. This offer will only remain in force until the 15th May, 1906. The company is doing a ateady and profitable business. The div denda paid for the past five years have been as fo'lows:- For 1901 7 per cent, for 1902 8 per cent., for 1908 8 por cent, for 1904 9 per cont. and for 1906 10 per cent.

div.head:
RAILWAY ACCIDENT IN FRANCE
CHERBOURG-PARIS BOAT TRAIN DERAILED.
div.p: (Gazetto's Special Servico.)

London, Tuesday. Telegrams from Paris to-day state that the boat train from Cherbourg to Paris, conveying the passengers of the Kaiser Wilhelm der Grosse, left the rails at Andresy. Three of the passengers were killed and six injured.

div.p: The S.S. City of Athens (Ellerman Line, N. B. Tamvaco, agent) is dae to arrive at Alexandria at noon on Thursday next with about 800 men of the 1st Battalion Lancashire Pusiliers from Malta.

div.head: San Stefano Club.
div.p: A general meeting of the members of the San Stefano Club was held on Sunday last, when the following committee was elected :Count M. Zizinia, hod.-president ; Mr. N. Kin. dineco, president; Dr. Zambacos, vice-president : Messrs. M. Begbian, Alfred Savignon. H. Beltran, A. Bogdadli, R. Chasseand, 8. V. Filus, An. L. Lytsika, Mobamed Taber Bey, and Omar Bey Saltan, members.

div.head: An Offensive Performance.
div.p: We hear that the French Consulate has proceeded against M. Gonnet Levy, the mapag. ing director of the company which has been giving a series of performances at the Ambassadeurs, Cairo, for holding the President of the Republic op to ridicule in a piece entitled Son Excellence n'est pas de bois. The articles of the Code ander which proceedings have been taken are Art. 26 of the Law of July 29, 1881 (Offense ao President de la Republique) and Art. 28 of the same law (outrage aux bonnes mears).
New Victoria Hotel at San Stefano.

This newly erected hotel is situated in the most fashionable quarter of Ramleb, and will open its doors on the 1st of June. The hotel, which is furnished in a most lozarious style, contains some 80 bedrooms, all facing the sea, saloons, smoking room, and private dining room. The handsome dining room with a large verandah all round it can accommodate some 400 guests. The service and oaisine will be of the highest class. The management will be in the hands of Mr. C. F. Raisig, late manager of the Carlton Hotel, Balkeley.

div.head: THE PLAGUE.
div.p: Sunday's bulletin records four fresh cases (two of which fatal) and three deaths in hospital at Desbna, two cases at Samalont, and five cases and three deaths in hospital in Ghirgeh district.

div.head: CENSUS OF EGYPT.
div.p: A special service for the general con as of the population of Egypt has been created at the Finance Ministry. Mt: Cecil Lewis has been appointed director general.

div.head:
THE BUDGET.
PENNY REDUCTION IN TEA DUTY.
div.p: COAL DUTY REPEALED.
LONDON, April 30.

The Budget shows a realised surplus during | 1905-6 of £3,466,000 : the estimated expen. | ditare during 1906 7 is £141,786,000 and the revenue £144,860,000 : thus, after the deduction of about £400,000 for contingencies, there is a disposable surplus of £2,700,000, of which it is proposed to devote £500,000 ard £500,600 of the Chinese indemnity, to the reduction of the public debt, making, with the ordinary provision and the surplus of 1905-6. a total reduction of £13,500,000. The balance of the garplas is to be devoted to the repeal of the coal daty, and the reduction of the duty on tea by a pony : the income tax, beer and spirit duties are to remain unchanged. (R.)

div.head: PRINCE OF WALES AT "GIB."
div.p: GIBRALTAR, April 30.
The Prince and Princess of Wales have arrived here.

div.head: FRENCH LABOUR WAR.. MANY ARRESTS.
div.p: Paris, April 30.

As a result of the discovery of certain doco. monts, several Labour agitators, Anarchists, Royalists, and Bonapartists have been arrested here and in the provinces, under a common charge of complicity in rebellion and Anarchist agitation. (Reuter)
Paris, April 30.

Four Anarchists were arrested yesterday, and among them the supposed author of the attempt on M. Loubet and King Alfonso. Other arrests have been made to-day, including that of the secretary general of the Conféderation du Travail. The garrison of Paris has been reinforced. Quiet prevails in the Pas de Calais. (Elavas)

div.head: HUNGARIAN ELECTIONS.
div.p: BUDAPEST, April 30.
The results of the elections known 60 far show that 138 Kossathites, 38 Constitutionale, and 12 Clerical Democrats have been returned. (Havas)

div.head: SUMMER TRAIN SERVICE.
div.p: The following are the changes made in the now train service which came into force today :
CAIRO TO ALEXANDRIA.
The evening expresses will leave Cairo and Alexandria at 6.35 and 6 p.m. respectively instead of at 4 50 and 4.25 p.m. Dining cars will be attached. Theze trains will convey third-class passengers.
The 12 noon luncheon car expresses between Cairo and Alexandria will continue during the summer and will stop at Sidi-Gaber.
The 2.10 p.m. from Alexandria has been re-timed to arrive at Cairo at 8.10 p.m.,instead of 8.35, and the 3 p m. from Cairo to arrive at Alexandria at 8.55 p.m. instead of 9.25.
The train which now leaves Alexandris at 16.50 p.m. for Tartah will leave at 7 p.m., conneeting at Sidi Gaber with the 5.10 p.m. from Rosetta.
CAIRO TO PORT SAID.

The present 8.0 a.m. mixed train from Ismailia to Port Said has been re-timed to leave Zagazig at 4.30 a.m. and to arrive at Port Said | at 10.55 am, and the train leaving Port Said at 2 p.m. for Ismailia will be extended to Zagazig, reaching there at 8.20 p.m.

The train now leaving Benha at 10.25 a.m. for Ismailia will only run to Zagazig, and the 11.0 a.m. Cairo to Port Said will stop at all stations between Zagozig and Ismailis, arriving at Port Said at 4 p.m.

The present 5.10 p.m. from Benha to Ismailie will run to Tel-el-Kebir only, and the 6.15 p.m. Cairo to Port Said will stop at all stations from Tel-el-Kebir to Ismailia, arriving at Port Said at 11.10 p.m.
The present 6.20 a.m. local train from | Ismailia to Benha will not run, and a new local train will start from Tel-el Kebir at 7.0 a.m. stopping at all stations to Bephs.
The local train leaving Ismailia now at 3 p.m. to Zagazig will not run, and the present 12.30 p.m. Port Said to Cairo will start at 11.55 a.m. and stop at all stations between Ismailia and Zigazig.
On the line between Mansourah and Zagazig, the train now leaving Mansourah at 9.50 a.m. will leave at 9.20 a.m. and arrive at Cairo at | 1.45 p.m. instead of 2.45 p.m.
On the Mansourab-Tantah line, a new train will be run in each direction, leaving Mansoorah at 6.5 p.m. for Tantab and Tantah at 8.15 p.m. for Mansourab.
On the Salhieh line, the train now leaving! at 10.50 a.m. and 5.55 p m. from Abop Kebir I will leave at 11 a.m. and 5.50 p.m.

On the Upper Egypt line, slight alterations have been made in certain training, especially in the night expresses from Cairo to Luxor, and in consequence of this, slight alterations have been introduced on the Luxor Asgonan lire trains as shown in the time-table.

On the Fayoum and Sennonres lines the t-ain which leaves Wasta at 9.14 p.m. will leave at 9.40 p.m. after arrival of the 8.0 p.m. from Cairo. This latter train connecting at Cairo with the 3.40 p.m. from Alexandria. Further the train leaving Fayoum at 9 p.m. for Sennoures will leave at 10.45 after the I arrival of the 9.40 p.m from Wasta.

div.head: THE FRONTIER DISPUTE.
div.p: KING'S HURRIED RETURN TO LONDON
SAILING OF U BATTERY.
NAPLES, April 80.
King Edward has left for London by rail via Modens.
LONDON, April 30.
It is understood that the King's decision to return home immediately, by rail, is owing to the Tarco-Egyptian situation.
U Battery rails for Egypt about the second week in May. (Router)

div.head:
TURKISH BLUFF.
"A DEPLORABLE MISTAKE."
div.p: The "Times" Correspondent at Constantinople says the prevailing opinion is that the Government has made a deplorable mistake, and that the reckless attempt to bloff Egypt and Great Britain can only end in humiliating | failure. The reports of an agitation amongst the native Egyptians, although they may encourage the obstinacy of the Palace, do not deceive well-informed Turks, who know the benefits which the British occupation has conferred upon the country and how highly these benefits are appreciated by the mass of the Egyptian population.

Great Britain is ready to discuss the matter in a friendly spirit, but insists on the restoration of the status quo as a necessary preliminary to the discussion. Great Britain displays great for bearance but this is not due to any | lack of determination to protect the interests - of Egypt.

div.head: THE GERMAN ATTITUDE.
div.p: The "Kolnische Zeitung" declares that Germany is not interested in the petty Akaba dispute.
The "Norddeutsche Allgemeine Zeitung" repudiates the idea that Germany is responsible for Tarkey's obstinacy and that she is seeking to undermine Great Britain's position in Egypt.
The "Berlin Post" says that Great Britain cannot allow the "status quo" to be distarbed, and that the sooner this is realised by Con. stantinople the better.(Reuter)

div.head: SITUATION AT RAFAKH.
div.p: "Al Mokattam" has received the following telegram from its correspondent at El-Areesh :
"In 8000"dance with your instructions, I went to Rafakh and have just returned. The following is the result of my investigations there.
The Tarks have really removed the two marble columns : there is no doubt about it.
They have taken possession of twelve poles belonging to the Egyptian Telegraphs and converted them into poles for the Tarkish telegraph.

"The Turks have penetrated Egyptian territory a distance of one kilometre past the Egyptian boundary pillars, in a westerly direction. There are ten Turkish tents there occupied by 50 Tarkish soldiers, under a Staff Yousbashi named Mufid Bey and a Mulazim Sani named Ismail Bey.

"The Tarkish officers deny the removal of the pillars and the other things imputed to them. I could not find out why they were camping at that spot; they concealed their real motives by making equivocal replies to my questions They said, "We are guarding our Ottoman territory, of which this land is a portion'."
Rafakh was occupied by the Turks 45 days ago.

div.head: NATIVE PRESS COMMENTS.
div.p: "Al Zaber" states that French influence is being exercised on behalf of Egypt, and appears to regret this proof that the "entente cordiale" Tis & permanent arrangement.

"Al Mokattam" states that Bedouins from Egyptian territory were mishandled by Turkish soldiers near Rafakh and lodged a complaint with the Egyptian Government. Emboldened by the fact that their conduct went unpunished the Tarks sent an officer with a party to camp Tst Rafakh. Next day the boundary pillars were gone. "Al Mokattam" adds that after this feat the Torkish troops advanced some distance across the frontier, and with them, according to the Bedouins, several pieces of artillery, one of which required eight horses to pull it.
"Al Moayad" denies that the Egyptian Government has given Great Britain a mandate to settle the frontier difficulty. It adds that it does not believe that Tabah will be surrendered by the Tarks.
"Al Lewa" advises calm. The frontier incident at Rafakh is, it states, sufficiently disproved by Ghazi Makhtar Pacha's dementi, which, it declares, has bɔon hailed with joy by the Egyptian people.
"Al Omma" hopes to have the chance of cheering the entry of the victorious Tarko into Cairo.

div.head: CONFUSION AT JEDDAH.
div.p: "Al Mokattam" learns that Jeddah is in a complete state of confusion, and that the foreign residents there are in a state of great alarm.
A large number of the Tarkish troops in Jeddah recently marched to Akabs, but several officers refused to leave Jeddah until they received half of their pay.

div.head:
THE ADMIRAL DEWEY.
GIVING TROUBLE IN THE CANAL.
div.p: DRY DOCK NEARING SUEZ
(FROM OUR CORRESPONDENT).
Port Said, Sunday

The Admiral Dewey is causing serious trouble in the Canal, as well as doing some considerable damage. As stated in Priday's isane, she entered the Canal at 7 a.m. on Friday, arrived at Kil. 14 at 9.40 a.m., and at Kil. 24 at 1.10 p.m., where she tied up in order to allow ships to pass. She proceeded at 2.20 a.m. yesterday and arrived at Kil. 54 at 11 p.m. last night. At this station great difficulty was found in mooring her. All the posts were broken as soon as the ropes were tied to them, and it was found necessary to pat a dozen or so more mooring posts in before she could be moored. These posts took some time to be fixed and it was not antil 6.20 a.m. to-day that she was made fast and ships were able to paga.
The Dewey bss the help of four tags and has three pilots, as well as several other Canal Company's officials, on board.
(FROM OUR CORRESPONDENT).
Saez, Sanday.

The floating dock Admiral Dewey, in tow of the Canal Company's tog Titan, was this morning Dear 54 Kil. station in the Canal, and during the last 24 hours has made very little progress. All traffic in the Canal is stopped, and they are endeavouring to bring the dock into a station in order to let the steamers pass. Owing to the difficulties caused, Mr. Schmid, principal agent of the Suez Canal Company at Saez, left this morning for Ismailia.
When the dock fioally reaches Saez, she will proceed at once to Manila in tow of the steamers, and not wait till the monsoon is over.
Saez, Monday.

The floating dock reached Ismailia this morning and proceeded very satisfactorily. She will anchor this evening in the Bitter Lake, and thance be towed to Saez. The most difficult part of the Canal to negotiate begins now, owing to the carves, but it is expected the dock will reach Saez very soon.

The U. 8. auxiliary Navy transports Cæser, Glacier, and Bratag are now anchored in the Bay waiting for the dock to proceed to the Philippines. The highest speed the tags attained towing the Dewey in goot weather was about 5 knots, but it is feared that towing through the monsoon will be found most difficult.

div.head: BRITISH SHIP AGROUND.
div.p: Saez, Tuesday.

The S.S. Hosley, of West Hartlepool, bound to Bombay with coal, grounded last Friday near Zatrana lighthouse in the Gulf of Saez in L. 29.20 N. Long. 32.36 B, and got off yesterday day without assistance after having thrown overboard about 100 tons of coal. The vessel apparently sustained no damage and proceeded.

div.head: CARIB PRINCE ASHORE.
div.p: A telegram from Algiers states that the British steamer Carib Prince is ashore on the beach. She has cradled herself in the sand and it will probably be necessary to discharge the cargo before she can be got off.

div.head: SANGANEB LIGHT.
div.p: A temporary light is now exhibited on the southern end of Sanganeb reef, close to the position of the old beacon. The light consists of a fourth order dioptrio light, showing a fixed white light through 366. The light is supported on an iron standard giving an elevation to the focal plane of fifty feet above high water, and is visible in clear weather about twelve miles.

div.head: BOATING FATALITY.
div.p: A sad accident has occurred at the Sacreries factory at Nag Hamadi, resulting in the death of Mr. Sch rmer and his son, agad twelve years. Mr. Schirmer, who was the storekeeper to the Sacreries Company, went out in a boat on Sanday, accompanied by his son, and the doctor and pharmacist attached to the factory, intending to pass the morning on the river. A squall appears to have capsized the boat, and Mr. Schirmer and his son were both carried away by the current and drowned.
Mr. Sobirmer's body has since been recovered and divers are searching for that of his son.
The deceased leaves a widow and two children.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL RECEPTION.
div.p: H.H. the Khedive will hold a reception at Ras-el-Tin Palace on Thursday next, on the occasion of his arrival at Alexandria.
The order in which visitors will be received will appear in tomorrow's issue.

div.head: LORD CROMER'S REPORT.
div.p: One of our contemporaries recently expressed its surprise that Lord Cromer's Report was not made public in Egypt at the same time as it appeared in England. Surely our contemporary forgets that the Report must first be published as a Parliamentary Paper submitted to the House by the Minister of Foreign Affairs.

div.head:
THE ARMENIAN COMMUNITY.
AGITATION AGAINST BARTAU PACHA.
div.p: OFFICIAL ENQUIRY OPENED.

The crisis in the affairs of the Armenian community at Alexandria shows no sign of abating, and the feeling against Bartan Pacha, the president of the community, is very strong. There will be a mass meeting of the members of the community on Saturday next, when it is proposed to elect a commission of three members, who will in their taro choose a notable of the Armenians to be president of the community.

It has been decided by the Alexandria Gouvernorat authorities to open an enquiry into the complaints made by the community against Bartaa Pacha and the members of the council. It is alleged that the council was illegally formed by Bartau Pacha and they want a new president elected. The object of the official enquiry is to discover whether there was any illegality about the formation of the council or any irregularity in the election of Bartau Pacha.

Peeling runs very strong among the com. monity, for it is felt that in such a wealthy and important community the choice of a president is a momentous one, and any irregularities should be rigorously put a stop to. Bartau Pacha has been for four years president of the community and it is not considered that he has filled the duties of his post to the general satisfaction.

div.head: DEATH OF MR. A. BENEDUCCI
div.p: We regret to announce the death of Mr. Antonio de Beneduooi, Congal at Alexandria for the United States of Mexico and manager of the Alexandria branch of Messrs. Walker and Meimarachi, Ltd. The deceased, who was 29 years of age, hed for three months past been suffering from Malta fever and left for Athens only a fortnight ago in apparent convalescence. But the change to Barope did him no good, and he slowly sank owing to the ex003sive weakness induced by the fever, and died yesterday morning. He had his mother and bis sister, Mrs. Constantine Meimarachi, and his brother with him at the time. His loss is mach regretted at Alexandria, where his management of Messrs. Walker and Meimarachi's stores had made him known to a large circle. We beg to tender our sympathies to the Bengdacci and Meimarachi families in their bereavement.
Messrs. Walker and Meimarachi's stores were closed to-day till 3 p.m. as a sign of mourning.

div.head: THE BAKERS' STRIKE.
div.p: Yesterday afternoon at 4 o'clock, the Governor of Alexandria received a number of representatives of the master bakers of the city. After a long discussion the Governor proposed & rise in wages equivalent to an increase of fifteen per cent, and also & decrease in the hours of work to ten per diem. This proposal was agreed to. Work was resumed generally to-day, but some of the masters refused to re-employ the strikers.

div.head: MARK MASONRY IN EGYPT.
div.p: The annual meeting of the District Grand Mark Lodge of North Africa was held in the spacious temple at Boulac-road, Cairo, on Batarday last, Idris Bey Ragheb in the chair as D.G.M.

After the usual business had been concluded, the "event" of the evening. viz., the ballot for the recommendation of a Bu00e88or as D. G. Master for the coming three years, was announced: Amongst those distinguished Masons who were nominated for this high and honourable office were W. Broe. Delanoy, Zouhny Pacha, P.D.D.G.M's, and W. Bro John Langley, P.G.M. The latter was elected by a large majority. W. Bro. King was unanimously elected treasurer.
It was unanimously agreed to present the retiring D.G.M. with a souvenir from the foods for his services during the last nine years.
The many friends of W. Bro. Langley will congratulate him on his well-deserved honour, and Mark Masonry may now be considered as entering on a new era.

div.head: LETTERS TO THE EDITOR.
div.p: We do not hold ourselves responsible for the opinions expressed by our correspondents, but we wish, in a spirit of fair play to all, to permit - within certain necessary limits free discussion.

div.head: RAMLEH SEWAGE NUISANCE.
div.p: TO THE EDITOR OF THE "EGYPTIAN GAZETTE"
Sir --Can anyone inform me what are the regulations (and penalties for breaches of same) concerning the disposal of sewage matter in Ramleh?

As the authorities I have invoked seem unable or unwilling to act, perhaps a little ventilation of the nuisance to which we are periodically subject may awaken those responsible to a sense of their duty. For the third time the contents of the cess-pit of the police caracol at Fleming, Ramleh, have been emptied on a small open plot of ground surrounded by houses, and to the windward of our house.
I report the matter in the public interest, and trust that in so doing SOMEBODY may be held accountable and a recurrence of the outrage prevented, -Yours, etc.,

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL.
div.p: We are glad to hear that Brewster Bey, Boglish secretary to the Khedive, is getting better. He has had a very sharp, serious attack and is looking pulled down, but he will, it is hoped, soon pick up if he oan get away for a change of air.
Ravenscroft Boy, assistant to the Director of the Slavery Department, has been promoted to the rank of local Miralai.
We regret to announce the death of M. Nessim Cariel.

Lieat.-Col. Gerald James Cathbert, who has been removed from the command of the 1st Batt. Scots Guards, and placed upon halfpay in consequence of the recent "ragging" scandal, was a most brilliant and popular officer, and his retirement has been received with keen regret at Aldershot. Col. Cathbert entered the army twenty-four years ago, and in 1885 served in the expedition to the Sadan with the 2od Batt. Soots Guards. He was present at the engagements at Hasheen and Temai, and for his services received the medal with clasp and the Khedive's Star. lo the South African war he again distinguished himself, and obtained the medal with six clasps and the King's medal with two clasps.

The British Army lost another capable officer in the retirement last week of Colonel Charles Napier Miles, C. B., M. V. O., who was formerly in command of the 1st Life Guards. Colonel Mile took part in Lord Wolseley's operations against Arabi Pasha in Egypt, and distinguished himself in the actions at El Magfar, Mahsameb, Kassassid, and Tel-el-Kebir, and the march on and occupation of Cairo. He was in charge of a composite regiment of Household Cavalry during the South African war, was mentioned in despatches, and received the Queen's medal with three clasps, and the Companionship of the Bath.

Dr. J. W. G. Allen, of Grimsby, who had been staying in Egypt for the benefit of his health, and who recently returned to England, died last week. He was one of the most respected surgeons ia Grimsby, and was interested in many philanthropic movements.

Mr. James Edward Tait, a director of Sir William Arrol & Co., engineers, and the designer of the great Nile bridge at Cairo, who died on February last, left astate of the value of £5,694. Mr. Toit was engaged in the construction of the Forth Bridge, and was in sole charge of the erection of the Tower Bridge,

div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE
div.p: (Anjourd'hui à midi et demis)
Les règlements de fin du mois étant proch 93, les affaires se font plas rares et la cote fléchit | légèrement

Ce marasme de notre marché durera vrai semblalement jusqu'au 4 courant, dernier délai de la liquidation d'avril. Mais à partir de cette date on prévoit une reprise rapide et notable sur nos valeurs éolides, Agricole, Delta Light,eto.
Ces prévisions sont d'autant plus légitimes que les marchés d'Europe sont beaucoup mieux tenus : la route française y remonte à 99.10, la Delta Light à 12 3/4 et l'Agricole à 10 1/4.

Au nombre des valeurs, qui ont cependant donné lieu ici à quelques transactions il faut citer l'Agricole qui a été traitée entre 10 et 10 1/16, la Delta Light entre 12 1/2 et 12 9/16, la Delta Land à 4 11/16 et l'Union Foncière à 6 11/16.
Cette dernière a même é é demandée à l'ouverture à 6 3/1, mais elle n'a pas tardé à fiéchir à 6 11/16 devant l'apathie générale.

L'Union Fonojère d'Egypte a été créée en juin dernier par les premiers financiers du pays. Dès sa formation elle a fait l'acquisition d'un terrain de 2000 feddaas au prix de L.E. 50 le feddan, terrain pour lequel on lui offre aujour. d'hui L.B. 85 le faddan ; mais la société ne le vend pas dans l'attente de plus hauts prix : elle en a déjà, en effet, vendu une parcelle du prix de L.E. 160 le feddan. La Société a pris en outre de la Béhéra plus de 2000 fed dans d ane moyenne de L. E. 36 le teddan. Cette propriété qui a été soigneusement choisie est estimée adjourd'hui à L.E. 80 le føddan. L'Union Foncière & encore acheté récemment À la Béhéra environ 6.90 foddang dont la con tiguïté avec 808 .précédents achats augmeots beaucoup la valenr par suite des facilités d'irrigation. Le coût total des acquisitions de la Société s'élève à LE 400,000. Le solde da capital, L.E. 100,000, sera consacré à des ter. rains à bâtir, en particulier à Alexandrie où des pourparlers sont en cours.

div.head: BANQUE INDUSTRIELLE D'EGYPTE
div.p: EN LIQUIDATION

Voici le bilan au 31 mars 1906 qui a été soumis par les liquidateurs au tribunal mixte de Commerce d'Alexandrie : (A l'actit la part terrain du Mex figare pour P.T. 66.459,3, les titres divers pour P.T. 807.562,5, les comptes irreconvrables pour P.T. 12.465.953,9, les comptes d'ordre pour P.T. 17.98 1,1, les espèces en caisse et dans les ban: ques pour P.T. 187.879,1 et le compte profits et pertés pour P.T. 17.01.701,1; soit un total de P.T. 30.647.040.
Le passif s'établit comme suit: Compte capital, déduction faite des répartitions d'actif effectuées, P.T. 30.500.000 et coupons impayés P.T. 147.040.

Il a été passé par profits et pertas ane somme de P.T. 743.397, 7 sur les actions Tramways du Nord-Ouest de Paris qui laisse ces titres figarer dans les livres à la valear qu'ils ont sotuellement, valeur qui, du reste, peat encore varier.

Ce qui empêche surtout la liquidation défi. nitive, c'est la liquidation des intérêts que la Bociété possède encore dans les Accumulateurs Phénix. Ces intérêts, quoque réduits malheureusement à ang somme minime, sont encore dépendants de certains essais de perfectionnement des brevets Phénix, que les liquidateurs ne peuvent se résoudre à sacrifier complètement.

div.head: SUCRERIES ET RAFFINERIE
div.p: D'EGYPTE.
Nous recevons la communication suivante da l'Association Nationale des portears françsis de valeurs étrangères, 5, rue Gaillin, Paris:

"Le Comité de défansa das obligataires de la Société des Sucreries et de la Raffinerie d'Egy pte vient d'être avisé officiellement par la société qu'elle va soumettre comme concordat de faillite à l'assemblée des créanciers, lorsque celle-ci sera convoquée par le jage commissaire, un projet identique quant au fond à celui qa'elle avait présenté comme concordat préventif, et en faveur daquel, en grande majorité, les créanciers s'étaient prononcés le 10 février dernier.

La société déclare en outre avoir pris toutes les dispositions nécessaires pour s'assorer l'adhésion et le concours des divers groapes intéressés qui étaient intervenus 20 projet de concordat préventif.

Le Comité espère être fixé très proch sidement sur la question des formalités qa'en. tralnera cette nouvelle consultation et il adressera aux porteurs une communication à cet égard avec un exposé de la situation.

div.head: THE CAIRO SUBURBAN BUILDING LANDS COMPANY.
div.p: Nous avons publié hier quelques renseignements sur la Cairo Saburban Bailding Lands Company dont l'émission aura lieu demain.

Nous avons parlé notamment da domaine de la Compagnie & Demerdache, mais ce que nous avons omis de dire, c'est que celai-ci ne lui revient qu'a P.T. 70 en moyenne par mètre carré, alors qa'il représente actuellement une plos valge considérable.

Outre qu'une nouvelle avende les reliera au boulevard Abbas et à Koubbeb, on sait qu'au milien de ces terrains va être édifiée une gare da chemin de fer électrique des Oasis d'Héliopolis, et que cette station sera l'unique point d'arrêt da dit chemin de fer ; on peut donc s'attendre à voir, à bref délai, s'y élever de nombreuses habitations et il y a lieu de croire, pensons-nous, que la nouvelle localité aura on succès plus grand encore que les Oasis enx. mêmes.

D'autre part, comme nous l'avons dit, la Société a déjà à l'étude, plusieurs projets im. portants qui se présentent dans des conditions exceptionnellement rémunératrices, et qui ont, on outre, l'avantage d'atre réalisables à bref delai. Elle s'est asgarée également le concours de | puissants groupes locaux et étrangers.

Le premier Conseil d'Administration est composé de MX. Montaga Sammers, Francis Rom, Alfred Carphey et 0. Rangabé Bey, qui tous sont parfaitement à même de mener à bien les affaires da genre de celles que comporte le but de la Société, et qui assureront, nous n'en doutons pa, à leurs actionnaires, le maximum de bénéfices réalisables.
Rappelons que les souscriptions ne seront reçues que demain seulement, aux guichets de l'Anglo Egyptian Bank. P.T. 50 sont payables à la souscription.
Il n'a été créé ni actions privilégiées, ni parts de fondateurs.

div.head: STRANDING OF THE EGYPTIAN PRINCE.
div.p: On the morning of April 10 we left London on board the Syrian Prinoe, bound to Alex andria and stopping at Malta for coaling and discharge of Government stores en route.
The night of the 9th had been unusually fair, the full moon beaming clear and bright on the few ships in the Tidal Basin, seeming to smile a good start-off and God-speed.

The Channel, the Bay, and the Mediterranean each oatvied the other in calm serenity, and when, ten days later, we steamed into the Grand Harbour at Malta it was so quiet that wa might almost have been gliding up the old River at home in a houseboat.

The sound of bells from many churches seemed to welcome us, and anch ships of the Mediterranean Squadron as were there at the moment dipped their colours. It was a gay and gallant sight, and later we discovered that Lord Charles Beresford way here, on H.M.S. Bulwark.

We spent that evening on deck, interested and amused spectators of our surroundings, and in bargaining with the vendors of Maltese lace, ivory and carved woods, who had boarded the ship with that object in view.
When we retired to our cabins all seemed! well, placidly, quietly well.
I was awakened by a sudden shout, and looked at my watch-4.30 a.m.
"Captain : Captain! Wake up, Sir! Steward! where are you ! Captain ! & ship has ran on the rocks, Sir--the Egyptian is aground close here."

By the time I had roused the occupant of the adjoining cabin the stewardess entered, saying that the company's agent had brought the tidings that the Egyptian Prince had gore on the rocks four miles distant at 8.30 the previous evening and that Captain Downs had mistaken the lights on shore.
We dressed quickly and went on deck, only to discover that our captain, Capt. Chilvers, had gone to the scene of the wreck, having first ordered that steam be got up lest we should be needed to help.

We gleaned from the agent that no lives were lost or endangered, and that the eight passengers, among whom were Mrs. James Knott and party, were all going to the hotel. Nothing was talked of but the wreck, and our own natural longing to be of some little aseof the pity of it all for the owner's sake and sympathy with those concerned in the accident.

A few hours later & party of four passengers went ashore, and mounting the steps to Strada Reale, we came suddenly across Captain Chilvers returning to the Syrian Prince. His usually merry face was drawn and baggard Looking, as one sometimes sees men after a prolonged and painful illness. We hurried towards him.
"What of the Egyptian? What news, Captain ?" His voice had an odd ring in it, and sounded as from a distance, and as if overheard rather than heard.
"News. Oh! yes, water is leaking into her ast, and if the wind gets up the rocks will her and she will be a total wreck. She is such a beautiful ship and her cargo is worth a quarter of a million.
"A terrible loss for the company", remarks Mr. S.

"Oh ! bow can you speak of it in a business one of voice!" cries Miss R. "I could fairly ry for them all Never again shall I read the Wrecks and Casualties' in the Daily Telegraph' as ordinary can't be helped eventually. What does the poor captain say?"
"Captain Downs is prostrate, white like a beet ! Sach a good fellow, too, and that's more he pity of it all."
The captain epoke with an effort, but stopping moment to light his pipe, and then contingng : "Mrs. Knott and party were on board and all seemed going 80 very well." "Is nothing being done?" we ask.
"Done 1 Oh, yes! Government togs are using ivery effort to get her off the rocks. So much ies with the wind. If it keeps calm the ship night possibly. be saved."
Captain Chilvers passed on, and we mounted the hill to church.

There was no litany in the service, but the prayer for all those "Who are in any way Micted or distressed in mind or estate" was ient op with bated breath and intense fervour by one, and may be all of us. "Great Power hat roleth winds, let there be calm for a space! Save the ship ! Save the treasure Great Inspirer of Life and Hope, give fortitude to the rashed spirit of the unfortunate captain and restore to the losers their own again, in thy 1, joundless, ineffable goodness, unworthy though we be who crave tby intervention"............

All Sanday after con and evening we stayed in the deck of the Syrian watching for, and mounting the lighters which were relieving the stranded vessel of her cargo and thus facilitating the chance of getting her off the rooks.
Lord Charles Beresford had gone on board 18 Boon as the accident was knowo. The prevalence of his lord: hip very naturally raised nope

and gave courage. He bid Captain Downs jpen out to him and "speak as to a father." On Monday two hundred blue jackets were working with might and main at hore - for there were six feet of water in the Egyptian by this time--at winches, and also helping to save the cargo. Three hundred Maltese were also employed in filling the lighters, which could easily be seen from the Syrian's deck in their passing and re-passing.
There was no slow of excitement in the syrian, only eyes looking strained and voices slightly hushed, and all our sea-going jokes and jingles were mum.d. Meals were taken in silence.
But the wind kept low; there was hardly A ripple in the barbour !
During the day the company's representative came on board, looking unusually worried for a Maltese
We circle round him for tidings. To our consternation be makes but one short, quick remark, with a kind of full-stop at the end.
"Carib Prince is gone ashore at Algiers !"
"How terrible ! Is it possible ! What an unheard-of coincidence ! When did it happen?" We ask.

"Same day as Egyptian disaster, Saturday | 21st." The agent proceeded to say that there I was no further tidings of the Carib Prince, beyond the bare fact contained in the telegram, and that in his opinion the Egyptian would be a total wreck, that Lord Charles Beresford was about, and that the bluejackets didn't like giving in.

On Tuesday evening Captain Chilvers came on board for an hour or so, looking as if he had suffered a wreck himself. He told us that hundreds of men were to work at the Egyptian throughout the night, and that much, and indeed most, depended on the wind keeping calm, thus preventing the rocks from goring holes in the vessel by continuous movement if swayed by wind and res. He added that should the night prove calm the Egyptian might be got off the rocks during Wednesday, the next day, in the morning.
Immediately after breakfast, therefore, we paced the deck, glasses in band, waiting, and hoping, and trusting, for there had been calm throughout the night.
Just about 11 o'clock there rang out in the distance a grand, great cheer from hundreds of voices.
This was but the forerunner of the glorious trath-the ship is saved, a precious treasure, restored!
The first officer handed me his glasses, while the chief engineer quietly remarked, "We may hope to see her brought into harbour at any moment now."
And there she comes, sore enough, with a Government tag on either side of her, and looking to an inexperienced eye peither crippled nor maimed.
But they did not bring her into harbour, but took her quietly into drydock. So all is better now.
Shortly after, our captain came on, and we steamed out and away on our course to Alexandria.
The wind rose and became fairly boisterous, but the calm had done its work.

At dinner that evening Capt. Chilvers gave as little details of the event, finishing by declaring, We were fairly choking when at last the Egyptian floated again. There was Mrs. Knott, in a boat, clapping her hands so heartily that she dropped her sunshade into the sea, and didn't seem to notice it!"

But it is a fact that we could never have managed without the bluejackets. Two years ago a ship was wrecked there, and for another two years I am told there will be a great white mark to show the spot where the Egyptian stranded.
S. R. (Passenger per S.S. Syrian Prince).

div.head: ALEXANDRIA MUNICIPALITY.
div.p: The following is the order of the day of the Municipal Commission which will be held to morrow:
1. Communications diverse.
1). Lettre du 25 Avril 1906 du Ministère de l'Intérieur relative à la mise en vente des terrains des quai.

2). Lettre du 22 avril da Ministère de l'Intérieur au spjet de la réglementation des poids et mesures. | 3). Lettre da 17 avril 1906, da Ministère de l'Intérieur communiquant la réglementation du canal Mahmoudieh.
4). Lettre du 26 avril da Ministère de l'In. tériear relative la cession à l'Université Magılmane da terrain des échèches da War.
dian. | 5). Lattre do 26 avril do Ministère de l'Inté. rieur relative à la construction de nouveaux ponts sur le Canal Mahmoudieh.
2. Demande de crédit de L E. 22 environ, pour travaux supplémentaires aq kiosque do service des Rocettes.
3. Rapport du Comité da Contentieux sur les amendes encourges par divers fournisseurs et entrepreneurs.

div.head: Circulaire H. De Vries et Boutigny
div.p: NOTES ET CRITIQUES

Le Caire, landi 30 avril. Le tapx de l'escompte à Londres & été, de nouveau, réduit de 1/8 à 3 1/4 pour cent. Avant-bier, au Stock Excbange, le Consolide anglais a réactionné de 1/4 à 90 3/8. L'Unifiée e, par contre, regagné 1/8 à 106 1/4. La National Bank a également clôturé en reprise de 1/8 à 26 5/8. L'Agricole est restée invariée à 10 3/8, de même que la Daïra à 17 5/8 et la Delta Light & 12 5/8.
A Paris, l'action Crédit Foncier Egyptien rattrapé 1 franc à 780. La Banque d'Athènes & réagi de 2 francs à 160.

Nous avons eu, ce matin, on marché calme, indécis et sans affaires, ce qu'il tant, assurément, attribuer aux règlements de fin de mois. En clôture, l'hésitation et l'abstention ont fini, il est vrai, par ressembler à de la faiblesse ;! mais on bers, apparemment; mieux demain ou les jours suivants. Le fait est que les mouvements considérables de fonds déterminés par l'emprunt rasse ont pris fin et que le marcbé monétaire européen est en train de retrouver son assiette. D'autre part, l'incident d'Ataba, qui remplace Algésiras dans l'ordre des préoc-1 oupations politiques, ne donne pas lien à des appréhensions graves. Le Divan cèders, ou ! bien on l'obligera à céder en agissant sur des points plus sensibles pour lui que le voisinage immédiat de l'Egypte.
La National Bank, délaissée, a doturé à 26 7/16-1/2. L'Agricole a fini à 10 1/32. Le Comptoir Financier a été ramené à 79/16.

Les jouissances Eaux du Caire ont monté juega'à 275 pour clotorer à 272 L'action Allotment a été également un peu mieox tende à 3 13/16-27/32. On apnonce que Sir William Willcocks sera de retour cette semaine de Chypre, où il est allé, comme on sait, regler les détails de la création d'une Banque Agri.. cole dans l'lle.

Les Improvements se sont ratpermis & 51/16 - 1/8. Il ne faut pas perdre de voe que ce titre est le meilleur marché de la cote, car sa valeur de liquidation est d'au moins £ 6. En outre, la Société fait presque tous les jours d'excellentes transactions. Ainsi pour les terrains Gianaclis (6,000 mètres) qu'elle vient d'acheter à £12 le mètre, elle a déjà acquéreur à £ 15; de ce seal chef elle peut réaliser un bénéfice de £ 18,000, ce qui représenterait le 18 % da capital sur dne seule affaire. La valeur se recommande donc tout particulièrement à l'achat.

Les Omnibus da Caire sont revenus à 29 1/2.! La forte baisse de la semaine passée doit être, i parait-il, attribuée à la formation d'une com.li pagpie concorrente qui serait créée par la Société des Tramways d'accord avec un groupe financier belge. On établirait un service de la correspondance entre trams électriques et omnibus automobiles. | Les Automobiles ont, de leur côté, fléchi à £6 1/2 vendears.
La Nile Land a été traitée à 15 1/4.

L'émission de la "Cairo Suburban Baildingle Lands Co" est fixée à après-demain mercredi 2 Mai. La souscription ne retara onverte que F ce jour-là seulemant aux guichets de l'Anglo-B Egyptian Bank an Caire et à Alexandrie.

La nouvelle Société a pour objet de faire toutes opérations immobilières, notamment d'acquérir, prendre et donner à bail tons immenbles, les exploiter, y édifier tontes oopstructions, les revendre au comptant ou à terme par annuités, etc.

Elle a déjà acquis, dans d'excellentes con ditions, on vaste terrain situé entre le pont de Gamrah et la station de Demerdache. Aa a miliea de ce terrain sera édifiée ane gare de, ci la Cairo Electric Railway! and Heliopolis le Oases Co., qui n'aura que ce seul point d'arrêt, to et y amènera les voyageurs de Pont-Limoun la en moins de cinq minutes. Les terrains de la d Société seront, en outre, reliés d'an côté par plusieurs grandes artères au boulevard Abbas et, de l'autre côté, à Koubbeh par une nous le vello avenue.
Le capital social, entièrement souscrit par v les fondatears, est de LE. 160,000, divisé end 40,000 actions ordinaires de L.E. 4 chacune. Il e n'ya ni actions privilégiées ni parts de fon- ri dateur.
Le premier conseil d'administration est composé de MM. Montagu Sommers, Frar cois! Rom, Alfred Carphey et de l'ingénieur 0. de le Rangabé bey.
Il est offert en souscription pablique 14,000 actions au prix de L.E. 41/4.
C'est une très belle affaire sous tous les rapports, et nous nous mettons à la disposition de = ceux de nos clients qui voudraient souscrire 1 par notre entromise,

Nous rappelons que la souscription aux &Ctions des Grands Garages d'Egypte, dont nous Ayodo parlé dans notre Circulaire de samedi passé, sera ouverte demain matin à 9h. a l'Anglo-Egyptian Bank, au Caire et à Alex-ta andrie, et clôturée le même jonr à 5b. p m.
On peut souscrire par notre entremice.

On annonce d'Anvers que l'assemblée extraordinaire de la Caisse Hypothécaire d'Egypte La porte le capital social de 5 à 10 millions de ! francs par la création de 10,000 actions pon-1 velles de Fra. [09 chacone. Le conseil a été ! antori-é à émettre les titres nonveaux en accord dant un droit de préférence pour la souscrip tion aux anciens actionnaires.

Sur chaque action nouvelle de Fre. 500, ila! Tété effectué par les souscripteurs un versement 1 de 25 % da capital nominal, auguenté de Frs. 195 de prime, ou Prs. 150 par titre, soit au total | 1.500.000 frarcs qui ont été versés dans les é caisses de la Société.

div.head: Municipalite d'Alexandrie.
div.p: AVIS

Par mesure de précaution contre l'apparition d'épidémios, et en conformité des arrêtés municipaux des 19 Janvier 1898 At 80 Jain 1901, le pablic est prévenu que le commerce, le transport et la manipulation des chiffons dans la ville d'Alexandrie sont saependas à partir du 1er Mai 1906.
Les chiffons transportés dans la rue seront Baisis et détroits sans aucune indemnité poor le propriétaire ou le destinataire.

Sont exceptés de cette interdiction les arrivages de chiffons en balles cerclées destinées directement pour le transport à l'étranger et expédiées de l'intérieur du pays avec une autorisation spéciale de la Direction générale des Services Sanitaires du Caire.
Toute infraction @ox présentes dispositions est passible des peines et sanotions prévues par les arrêtés précitée.
L'Administrateur,
W.P. CHATAWAY.
Alexandrie, le 27 Avril 1906. 27808-3-1

div.p: This Prospectus has been duly filed with the Registrar of Joint-Stock Companies, London,
The Commercial, Industrial and Land Company of Egypt, Ltd.
(Incorporated under the English Companies Acts, 1862-1900). Capital:£300,000
Divided into 295,000 Ordinary Shares of £1 each,
and 5,000 Deferred Shares of £1 each.

The Ordinary Shares are entitled to Dividends in priority to the Deferred Shares up to 7 per cent. in each year, and subject thereto to 60 per cont, of the balance of the profits available for distribution as dividend in each year, the Deferred Shares being entitled to the remainder of such balance.

In the event of the winding-up of the Company, the Capital paid up, or credited as paid up, on the Ordinary Shares will be repaid in priority to that paid up, or credited as paid up, on tho Deferred Shares, and any surplus assets remaining after repayment of the Capital paid up, or credited as paid up, on all the Shares, will be divided hg to 60 per cent. Amongst tho Ordinary Shares, and ds to the remainder Amongst the Deferred Shares.
200,000 Ordinary Shares are now offered for Subscription at Par
Payable : 28. per Share on Application, 3s. on Allotment, and the balance in three instalments of 5s.each at intervals of Two Months.
£100,000 OF THIS ISSUE HAS BEEN UNDERWRITTEN IN EGYPT.
Share Warrants to Bearer will be issued if required, after the Shares are fully paid.
All Dividends will be paid Free of English Income Tax. Ten thousand of the Ordinary Shares

and the whole of the Deferred Shares will be issued to the Vendor Company as fully paid in satisfaction of the purchase and other considerations mentioned in this Prospectus.The issue will be made simultaneously in England and Egypt.

div.head: PROSPECTUS.
div.p: OBJECTS.

This Company has been formed for the purposes set forth in the Memorandum of Association, and particularly for the purpose of acquiring and developing industrial and other undertakings in Egypt and the Sudan, including the securing of Land Concessions, the development of Building Estates, and the contracting for Building and Engineering Work, and subsequently dealing therewith either by re-sale to Subsidiary Companies or otherwise.
PROGRESS.

The progress of Egypt for many years past and the prosperity of the country under British control have been remarkable, proof of which is found in the various Reports and Official Publications from time to time issued by or with the sanction of the Egyptian Government.

Extensive Government irrigation schemes have opened up new districts, railways are being extended and towns are being developed, whereby a growing demand for capital has been created for industrial concerns of every description. In this connection the "Egyptian Gazztte" recently stated :

"Many of the shops and trading businesses can be amalgamated and controlled to the advantage of all concerned. It is the duty of "inance to organise the matter, and to provide the necessary capital. The Cairenes will welcome such efforts, and the success of trading concerns, if properly capitalised and properly managed, will be colossal during the next decade."
POPULATION.

The population has increased very rapidly owing to the constant stream of emigrants coming from all parts of Barope. The Baropean population of Cairo has doubled itself within the last three years, and the total population of the city and its immediate neighbourhood to-day is estimated to be one million.
RISE IN LAND VALUES.
As a natural consequence of this growth the value of land has during the past five years largely increased owing to the demand for building sites and agricultural areas.
An era of great prosperity having been thus inaugurated, there is an extensive field in Egypt for the profitable employment of capital under circumstances of an unusually advantageous character.
OPTIONS.

This Company has already obtained Options which enable it to acquire for development, should the Directors elect, the following businesses and properties (more detailed particulars of which, as set out in the Option Contracts or supplied by the Vendor Company, are enclosed with this Prospectus).

a) The business of R. Kaster and Co., of Boulac and Zaptieh, in Cairo, and of Alexandria, Engineers and Iron Merchants,established in 1869, and 6,139 Square metres of Freehold Land on which their Cairo premises are built
b) The business of Elgar Kirby and Co., Sanitary Bazineers and Government Contractors, of Cairo, Alexandria and Mansourah, established for nineteen years
c) The business of Mardooh and Templeton, Engineers and Contractors, of Mansourah, established in 1881.

d) The business of the Mansourah Electric Supply Company which has the monopoly ander a concession of the supply of electric light to the town of Mansourah (which has been working since 1901), and the accounts of which show an increasing revenue. The proprietors are the above-named Murdoch and Templeton.
e) A Freehold Building Site of about three acres in extent in the Island of Rodah, which is considered one of the most favoured positions for residential purposes.

The value of the Options consists not only in the businesses themselves, but also in the freehold land included therein, and two of the Local Advisers of the Company have shown their confidence in the success of this undertaking by underwriting £50,000 of the present issue.

The trading profits of the above-mentioned basinesses A, B, C, and D are not set out in this prospectus inasmuch as the businesses are under option only ; but the owners have disclosed in confidence to the Vendor Co. the figures of their average net profits for the last seven years, and the Vendor Company states it has carefully checked the figures given with the books and the accounts of the various businesses and has found them to be correct. On the basis of these figuras, which show a profit of 10% the Directors are of opinion that by amalgamation, central control, and consequent economy, the profit already earned by the businesses can be materially increased.
VENDOR AND PURCHASE CONSIDERATION.

The Vendor Company is the Westminster Industrial and Finance Developments Limited, of 3, Princes' Mansion, Victoria Street, in the City of Westminster, who by an agreement dated 20th April, 1906, has agreed to sell the above-mentioned Options to this Company. Tha Vendor Company states that in obtaining these Options it has incurrel considerable trouble and expense, including several journeys to Egypt ; but it asks for no remuneration therefore and for such Options other than Shares in the Company, and the repayment of the expenses attending the promotion and it has accordingly fixed the purchase price thereof at £14,000, payable as to £10,000 in fully paid Ordinary Shores of this Company, and as to the balance of £4,000 in fully paid Deferred Shares of this Company.
PRELIMINARY EXPENSES.

By the same agreement the Vendor Company has agreed to pay all the costs of the preliminary Agreements and the Memorandum and Articles of Association of the Company, and the registration thereof, and all stamps, fees and legal expenses, and generally all the preliminary expenses whatsoever, including fees of Brokers and Solicitors, the costs of printing. issuing and advertising this Prospectus, both in Bogland and Egypt, and its translation for the latter purpose into both French and Arabic, and all printing, stamping, and allotment letters, in consideration whereof there is to be fol paid to it by this Company the sum of £9,000, tel in cash and £1,000 in fully paid Deferred shares of this Company.
The preliminary expenses (exclusive of the brokerage hereinafter mentioned) are estimated at £9,000.
UNDERWRITING ARRANGEMENTS.

This Company has also entered into an agreement with the Vendor Company dated 20th April, 1906, whereby the former has agreed to pay the Ven lor Company the sum of £4,000 in cash, in consideration of the Vendor Company procuring subscriptions for 100,000 of the Ordinary Shares of this Company now offered for subscription, being at the rate of 4 per cent. thereon. Of this sum £2,500 is payable to the underwriters named in the underwriting agreements mentioned below.
This company will pay brokerage of 3d. per share on all allotments made to the public in England on applications bearing brokers' stamps.

The amount fixed by the Articles of Association as the minimum subscription on which the Directors may proceed to allotment is 10 per cent. of the Shares offered for subscription, but the Directors will not proceed to allotment on less than £100,000.
CONTRACTS.
The following are the material Contracts entered into :

(1) Agreement made between R. Kuster & Co. and the Vendor Company contained in two letters both dated the 21st February, 1906, whereby R. Kaster & Co. gave to the Vendor Company an option until the 12th May, 1906, to purchase their business, including stock, book debts and plant for the snm of £85,018 E, and a further option to purchase the freehold of the land on which the Cairo premises stand at the price of £19,982, the total purchase price being thos £135,000 E, payable as to £60,000 in cash, and the balance in fully paid shares of this Company. The stock is valued at £35,400 E, the book debts at £29,300 E, and the plant and machinery at £4,000 B, and the land at $49.982 B, a total of £118,682, so that £16,318 is payable for goodwill. (2) Agreement between Edgar Kirby & Co. and the Vendor Company contained in two letters both dated the 1st March, 1906, whereby Edgar Kirby & Co. gave to the Vendor Com pany an option to purchase their business, inclusive of stock, at the price of £31,000 sterling, payable as to £15,000 in cash and £16,007 in fully paid shares of this Company, the stock being valued at £15,000, 80 that £16.000 is payable for goodwill. (3) Agreement between Mardooh and Templeton and the Vendor Company, contained in four several letters dated the 21st December, 1905, and the 9th, 15th and 26th February 1906, whereby Mardoch and Templetou gave to the Vendor Company an option to purchase their business, inclusive of the stock, for the sum of £30,000 sterling, payable as to £28,000 in cash and £3,000 in fally paid abares of the Company. Nothing is payable for goodwill. (1) Agreement between Murdoch & Templeton and the Vendor Company, contained in three several letters dated the 91st December, 1905, and 13th and 18th February, 1906, whereby Mardgoh & Templetɔn gave to the Vendor Company an option to purchase their electric light concession at Mansourah for the sum of £21,009 in cash. (5) Agreement between L. Coscarelli, of Cairo, and the Vendor Company, contained in two letters dated the 16th November, 1905, and the 26th February, 1906, as to the purchase of the Rodah Island building site for the period of 30) piastres per square metre (6) Agreement dated the 10th March, 19 6, between the Vendor Company of the one part, and Guston John Weise of the other part, whereby the said G. J. Weiss agreed to underwrite or obtain responsible applications for not less than 100,000 of the Ordinary Shares of this Company, to advertise the Prospectos of this Company in Egypt, and to perform other services in connection with its promotion, in consideration whereof the Vendor Company agreed to pay to him the sum of £2,500 in cash, £3,2-0 in fully paid ordinary Shares of this Company, and £1,000 in fully paid Deferred Shares of this Company. (7) Letter dated 10th March, 1906, ander which the said G. J. Weiss stipulates that his name shall appear on the Prospectus as broker to this Company. (8) Four severa! Underwriting Contracts, three whereof are dated the 10th March, 1906, and the other the 11th March, 1906, whereby Osman Bey Cheril, A. W. Goldenberg & Co., Walter Ablitt and the said Gaston John Weiss each agreed to underwrite 25,000 Ordinary Shares of the above issue for a commission of 25 per cent. in cash. (9) Agreement dated the 20 h day of April 1906, being the above-mentioned l Agreement for Sale, whereby the Vendor Company agreed to transfer the aforesaid options to this Company, and gave to this Company an option to purchase the Rodah 1 lard building site for the price of 300 piastres per square metre. (10) Agreement dated the 20th day of April, 1906, between this Company and the Vendor Company, being the above-'. mentioned agreement by the Vendor Company to procure subscriptions for 100,00 Ordinary Shares of the Company

Copies of the above-mentioned Contracts, together with a print of the Memorandum and Articles of Association of the Company (a copy of which Memorandum is printed on the back of this Prospectus and form part thereof) may be seen at the Offices of the Solicitors of the Company, at any time during business hours before the list of subscriptions is closed.
The Articles of Association contain the following provisions as to qualification and remuneration of the Directors :
DIRECTORS' QUALIFICATIONS.

The qualification of every Director is the holding of shares of the Company of the nominal value of £250, except that prior to the date of the Statutory Meeting sach qualification is the holding of one share.
DIRECTORS' REMUNERATION.

As remuneration for their services each of the Directors shall be paid out of the fonds of the Company at the rate of £200 in each year, with an additional remuneration at the rate of £50 per annum for the Chairman. In addition, if in any year 7 per cent. is paid by way of dividend on the Ordinary shares, then 5 percent of the net profits, after deducting therefrom the amount absorbed by such 7 per cent dividend, shall be paid to the Directors by way of additional remuneration. Sach remuneration by way of percentage shall be divided amongst the Directors in snob proportions and manner as they shall from time to time agree, and in default of agreement equally; and any Director holding office for part of a year shall be entitled to a proportionate amount of such remuneration. Each Director shall also be paid or reimbursed his reasonable travelling expenses (including travelling to attend Board Meetings whilst employed on the business of the Company). The Company in General Meetings may increase the amount of such remuneration either permanently or for a year longer term.
The Directors have also power to grant to any Director required to go abroad or to render any other extraordinary services, such special remuneration for such services as they think proper.

The Directors may from Sime to time appoint one or more of their body to be Managing Director or Managing Directors of the Company, either for a fixed term or without any limitation as to the period for which he or they is or are to hold such office, and may from time to time fix his or their remuneration, which may be by way of salary, or commission, or by participation in profits, or by any or all of these moder.
A settlement and quotation on the London and Cairo Stock Exchanges, and each other Exchanges as the Direcotors may think desirable, will be applied for in due course.

Application for Bhares phald be made on the form accompanying this Prospectus, and sent to the Banker with & Cheque for the deposit drawn in favour of the Bankers. Where no allotment is made the deposit will be returned in full, and where the number of shares allotted is less than that applied for, the balance of the deposit will be applied towards the remaining payments, and the surplus, if any, returned to the applicant. If default is made in payment of any instalment the instalments already paid will be liable to forfeiture.
Dated the 1st day of May, 1906.

Subscriptions open for ONE DAY ONLY. The Subscription will be opened at THE ANGLO-EGYPTIAN BANK Ltd. in CAIRO and ALEXANDRIA on WEDNESDAY, the 2nd MAY 1908 at 9 am and will close the same day at 5 pm.

Prospectuses and Forms of Applications can be obtained in Cairo at the Anglo-Egyptian Bank and at the Offices of Messrs. Rom, Vanderlinden & Co., Bankera, Sharia Kasr-el. Nil and in Alexandria at the Anglo-Egyptian Bank.

div.head: PROSPECTUS.
div.p: The Company has been formed for the purpose of acquiring, under exceptionally favourable terms and conditions, certain lands situated between the Pont de Ghamrah ard Demerdache Railway Station (Bgyptian State Railways) which will be brought to within five minutes of the heart of Cairo by the construction at a central point on the Company's State of a Station which will be the only stopping point on the Cairo Electric Railways ard Heliopolis Oasis Coy's Line between Pont Limoun and the Oasis of Abbassieh.

Other equally-if not more important advantages will acorde to the Lands now acquir. ed, by reason of the probable immediate construction of important thoroughfares passing through the Estate, and joining the Boulevard Abbas, the widening of which is now in active progress, whilst the projected new A vende to the Palais de Koubbeh will entail the construction of an imposing "passage" at the Pont de Gamrah thus bringing that part of the lands parobased situated on the left side of the Matarieh Railway to a point of valae almost on a par with the rest of the Estate.

With such physical advantages as those mentioned, in addition to the favourable position occupied by the Estate, it does not require the knowledge of an expert to see that the realisation of it in conveniently sized lots at much enhanced prices will be a matter of comparative base, particularly in the hands of those immediately connected with the Company, whose experience in this class of business is well-known.
The whole of the Capital of the Company has been subscribed as follows : - F. Rom, of Rom, Vander'inden

If the Number of Shares allotted be less than that applied for, the surplus will be credited to the applicant on account of the amount due on allotment, and any further excess will be returned to him.
Failure to pay any instalment when due will render all previous payments liable to forfeiture, and all overdue payments shall bear interest at the rate of 8 % per annum.

Emission de traites et chèques, émission de lettres de Crédit, paiement par télégraphe sur les principales villes de la France et de l'étranger;
Garde de titres;
Recourvement d'effets sur l'Egypte et l'étranger;
Le Crédit Lyonnais reçoit des fonds ou un compte de dépôt et délivre des bons à échéance fixe aux taux suivants:
2% aux bons de 1 an et au-delà.
